ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We also utilized pre-recorded lectures.
Recorded lecture
Recorded lecture
There was a recorded every week by different members of the faculty. The main format of the class, however, was a 50 minute zoom seminar that met thrice a week.
Recorded lecture, live colloquia
virtual seminar + weekly recorded lecture

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I developed an understanding of how to confront complex texts.
How to approach philosophical readings, discussions, and writings. The fundamentals of approaching and learning philosophy.
I learned how to write out in premise-conclusion form and then analyze arguments in a text, identify the weak point of the argument and discuss ways that weakness can or cannot be resolved.
I learned about the history of the western philosophy and the main aspects of some key philosophical thinkings.
I learned about several philosophic ideas and themes from antiquity. I learned how to develop counterarguments and exceptions, write arguments clearly, and conduct philosophical analyses.
I learned how to think and criticize things that I took for granted. I leaned that even basic assumptions can be broken down.

I got a broad overview of the development of philosophy from Early Ancient Athens to Medieval Christian Europe. More practically, I learned how to reason and write philosophically although this was a bit of a trial-and-error process. I also learned how to critique arguments not only logically but reasonable because sometimes one can pick apart an argument through low hanging fruit without really saying anything substantive.

I also became a better reader of philosophy; while some of the texts we read were cleanly expressed schematics of concrete ideas, others were dense and messy. After constantly reading dozens of pages of argument every week, I came to digest and skim this content more efficiently and meaningfully.
I learned how to write a philosophy paper, how to deconstruct an argument, and what the ideas of ancient philosophers were.
Structure and function of a philosophy paper, how to generate a reconstruction of a philosophical argument, an overview of the foundational views of seminal classic philosophers

charitably evaluating philosophic arguments (e.g. premises, soundness, validity, raising substantive objections); introduction to specific classical and medieval philosophers and schools including Plato, Aristotle, Epicureans, Stoics, Skeptics, etc

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think this was course was strong in that we analyzed texts at a high level. At the same time, because of the volume of things we read, it was often difficult to understand everythin. We would cover only a few pages out of readings that were signficantly longer.
Great course, one of my two favorite DS strands.

The strength of DS philosophy is its syllabus. I feel the works we read are representative of the key aspects of the western philosophical tradition. The reading load is not heavy, especially compared to the other two DS classes in my opinion. The major weakness is that I feel this particular section is sometimes a little bit disorganized. We just talks about whatever comes up and I'd prefer a more systemic and organized way of learning, at least for an introductory class on history of philosophy like this one. In my opinion, the materials don't get into the kind of depth that can support any meaningful conversation without significant guidance from the instructor.
Discussion was very thought provoking and interesting. However, too much time spent on Aristotle. Rushed through some of the later authors.
For this semester, I thought it was the best it could be. I thoroughly enjoyed it.

The syllabus is excellent. I like how its thoroughly canonical so we see how each other is in conversation with the last one; at the same time, the inclusion of philosophers like Ibn Tufayl is an example of how canonical doesn't mean homogeneous.

I also think the format of writing three five page papers is good; it's enough to develop solid skills without being too grueling.

The weakness for me was the discussion section. It often felt like the professor really carried the class, asked pointed questions and rarely did the whole section have valuable contributions. I'm not sure what the problem was -- likely a combination of how much reading people do and confidence speaking in a group -- but it didn't quite live up to the socratic, student-led discussions I had imagined.

The strengths of this course are that there were a lot places for feedback from the professor in regards to the essays at any point of the writing process. One of the weaknesses of this course is the huge amount of reading that needed to be done that were sometimes really dense and hard to understand.

Strengths: broad overview of material, substantial feedback given on assignments to improve between them
Weaknesses: lack of diversity of thought, prominence of a few speakers within seminar who dominated discussion, not enough focus or time spent on each work studied

Strengths: close analysis of classical and medieval philosophers, opportunity to substantively engage with their arguments (objecting to and/or defending them) in papers and seminars, Professor Greco is really good at closely dissecting arguments while keeping an eye on the bigger picture to keep the conversation going.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think the discussion worked well despite Zoom and the incorporation of the chat was also helpful in philosophy. People could provide thoughtful links or add smaller clarifying points.
PDF books were very accessible, but reading online PDFs was not the greatest. Not only could annotations not be made, but it contributed to the excess of screen time.
Virtual DS ends up nicely.
Seminar transition to online worked very well, I think the course went as well as could be expected
As I said, I think that this course was fine. The small seminar format was ideal for learning online.
Overall, it was very covid friendly. There are useful features of Canvas like the forum which are especially helpful during Covid. This could have been utilized even more.
Posting the lectures to be viewed at any time and having some sort of office hours before and after class were helpful.

I thought the discussion feature on Canvas could have been utilized more. Engaging with peers about the material before seminar would have given me a better understanding of the content before going into discussion. Zoom meetings with the professor were helpful, and overall I thought Zoom seminars went very well.
Zoom seminars with occasional breakout rooms worked fairly well. Lecture quality and engagement, since it was recorded, really varied a lot depending on  the lecturer.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this course. I developed an understanding of a wide range of philosophical frameworks and how to approach them.
Yes, learning how to think and inquire in a philosophical fashion is a valuable practice for anyone.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student. The texts are difficult to understand, but seminars make them much more approachable and there's nothing more satisfying than dissecting and explaining a complex argument.

Since I can't recommend this course alone, I would recommend the DS program to any student who is remotely interested in the foundation of the western thought. This philosophy section in particular doesn't end up as enlightening as my Literature and H&P sections, but it still does an adequate job on providing an overview of the history of the western philosophy up until Aquinas.
No, the Aristotle readings felt tedious, and less rewarding than the other DS classes. Other aspects of the class went fine.
Yes, but only if they are up for the reading material.

Wholeheartedly. The professors are excellent and they provide detailed feedback to improve your writing. Furthermore, the discussions give you a chance to entertain different opinions and you'll come away with a limited but impressive knowledge base.

I would recommend this course to students that are interested in the ancient philosophers and the ideas they had and philosophy, in general. Otherwise, I think the readings may be too much and too hard.

I would recommend this course to students who have a genuine interest in classic philosophy. This course was a great introduction to early philosophic thought, and I do feel that I have a strong foundation with which to proceed in my academic career. However, I would not recommend this course to students like me, who are pursuing a pre-law track, because I found it difficult to fully engage with the material without a strong interest in the content itself.

Yes. Reading philosophers from millennia ago definitely takes time and getting used to (I'm especially thinking of Aristotle), but I have found the experience surprisingly relevant to the questions we continue to ask today. Questions the classical and medieval philosophers treat, like "what is virtue?", "how is the existence evil compatible with an omnipotent and omniscient God?", or "how does one achieve happiness?", are timeless questions that are as relevant today as they were thousands of years ago. Even if the works you read in this class don't give you definitive answers to these questions, they certainly shed light on their complexity and suggest possible leads. I think this experience is invaluable even if you don't intend to rigorously study philosophy. Whether we like it or not, the answers and perspectives these philosophers suggested shaped history and the world today, whether it's the influence of Augustine's formulation of free will on Christian theology, or countless allusions to the Platonic images of Sun and Cave in literature and beyond (e.g. in Dante's Comedia, which you read in DS Lit), so it's important to understand, I think, where these ideas came from and how their authors framed it.
